text: [Music]
well um in my professional office we
have all the computers and lots of the
bells and whistles that are around I
personally still make little little
drawings and I like to use sculptor's
modeling clay which uh I was introduced
to by Lis Khan who used it but it goes
back in the architectural terms the mod
to the bozar tradition and in art terms
in general to to the tradition of
sculpture and I like to shape things and
mush them around and play with shapes
and then but of course then we use other
digital fabrication techniques or
whatever and then I certainly realize
that you can build things in
extraordinary ways that you couldn't um
do even 30 years ago so uh it affects me
but you know you can't you can't you can
teach an old dog some new tricks but you
can't teach them all new
tricks no I still think the Parthenon is
about uh way up there on the top so no I
don't think that in that sense it's
improved it's made more possibilities
and it has resulted in some buildings of
extraordinary beauty as any other
situation has frankly I think all these
glass buildings and I now I know I sound
like an ancient mariner or something but
uh producing a a bland uniformity um in
our cities including our city of New
York that is a a question how much glass
is appropriate and I'm I use glass as
the symbol of the new technology
